title: 103_hr1956
content: The "Minimum Tax Reform Act of 1993" is the short title of the Act. Any reference to an amendment or repeal in the Act is considered to be made to a section of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Section 2 deals with the depreciation adjustment used in computing alternative minimum taxable income. The "Minimum Tax Reform Act of 1993" addresses the depreciation adjustment for alternative minimum taxable income. It amends section 56(a) to include the 150-percent declining balance method for depreciation under section 167. The "Minimum Tax Reform Act of 1993" amends section 56(a) to include the 150-percent declining balance method for depreciation under section 167, including property defined in section 1250(c). The "Minimum Tax Reform Act of 1993" introduces the 150-percent declining balance method for depreciation under section 167, including property defined in section 1250(c). Additionally, it specifies the normalization method of accounting for public utility property under section 168(i)(10) and excludes property placed in service after December 31, 1992, from depreciation adjustments for computing adjusted current earnings. The "Minimum Tax Reform Act of 1993" introduces the 150-percent declining balance method for depreciation under section 167, including property defined in section 1250(c). It also exempts environmental improvement assets from depreciation adjustments under section 56(a)(1)(B). The term 'environmental improvement asset' refers to tangible property eligible for depreciation under section 167, used for purposes such as source reduction, waste minimization, recycling, and compliance with environmental regulations. The curr_chunk discusses the criteria for property to be considered an environmental improvement asset, including noise level regulations and the use of alternate fuels. It specifies that property must be located and used exclusively in the United States to qualify. The curr_chunk defines terms related to environmental protection, such as source reduction, solid waste minimization, and waste conversion or recycling. The curr_chunk further defines terms related to environmental protection, including waste conversion or recycling, abatement of environmental hazards, and unplanned releases. The curr_chunk defines regulated substances as those prohibited, limited, or regulated by federal or state laws. It also defines release as any spilling, leaking, pouring, discharging, escaping, dumping, or disposing into the environment. The effective date for these amendments is after December 31, 1992. The curr_chunk discusses allowing pre-1993 minimum tax as a credit against minimum tax for certain taxpayers. The amendment allows taxpayers with pre-1993 unused minimum tax credits to apply at least 50 percent of the excess tentative minimum tax as a credit in following taxable years. The amendment allows taxpayers to apply excess tentative minimum tax as a credit in following taxable years, limited by pre-1993 unused minimum tax credits. The amendment defines the testing period as the 5-taxable year period ending with the taxpayer's last taxable year beginning in 1992. Pre-1993 unused minimum tax credits refer to credits remaining unused at the close of the testing period. Conforming amendments include renumbering paragraphs and inserting new provisions. The effective date for the amendments made in this section is for taxable years starting after December 31, 1992, with paragraphs (1) and (2) being redesignated as subparagraphs (A) and (B). SEC. 4 allows for a general business credit against a portion of the minimum tax, with the effective date for this amendment being taxable years beginning after December 31, 1992.
